text: A New York Times story that purports to detail how little President Trump has paid in federal income taxes has handed Democrats what they hope will be a potent campaign message.
Trump Dismisses 'New York Times' Report That He Paid Little In Federal Income Taxes
A Look At Amy Coney Barrett's Record On Abortion Rights
Fighting Between Armenia And Azerbaijan Threatens To Spiral Into Full-Blown War
Ahead Of 1st Presidential Debate, Almost 1 Million Americans Have Already Voted
The two presidential candidates will face off for the first time in a debate moderated by Fox News' Chris Wallace.

Since 2016, journalist Yvonne Latty has been documenting her mother's journey with Alzheimer's disease. As part of a collaboration with Latino USA and Black Public Media, she brings this intimate portrait to NPR.
Tony Schwartz, co-author of Trump: The Art Of The Deal, talks about his new book and the recent New York Times report exploring President Trump's tax records.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi outlined the once far-fetched scenario in a letter to Democrats this weekend and is calling for more financial support for battleground candidates.

According to neuroscientists who study laughter, it turns out that chuckles and giggles often aren't a response to humor; they're a response to people. "Laughter is a very good index of how we feel about the people that we're with," neuroscientist Sophie Scott says.
It feels like a minor miracle that there are so many high-quality shows coming to the small screen this season. Four NPR critics share their picks to keep you entertained during a challenging year.
The U.S. Tax Court has repeatedly said that even for a public personality, the costs of maintaining an appealing appearance are not deductible.
The Consider This team wants to know how you're making decisions six months into the pandemic. What are you comfortable doing? What are you still unsure about?
We know we're not the only ones getting worried about winter during a pandemic. Rachel Miller of Vice joins Life Kit to talk about ways we can make the coming months a little easier.
Plus, of all U.S. homes that include someone with a disability, 63% report serious financial hardship during the pandemic, and 37% have used up all or most of their savings.
Sarah Deer, citizen of the Muscogee (Creek) Nation and University of Kansas professor, discusses the measures to strengthen investigation procedures and why it's taken so long to address the issue.
Brad Parscale's wife called police out of concern for her husband's safety. In July, Parscale was demoted from his role as the campaign manager of President Trump's reelection effort.

The Montanas were in their Malibu, Calif., home when a woman walked in and snatched the 9-month-old child from a playpen, officials say. Jennifer Montana had to pry the child from the intruder's arms.
Regulators had refused to renew Uber's license, finding its lax security controls had put passengers at risk. But a court found that Uber had fixed the problems and was fit to operate in the city.
Young people are known for taking to the streets in protest, but less so at the ballot box. An advocate, 19, from Los Angeles says lowering the age limit could foster a generation of loyal voters.
Kids don't often get to read stories about Latinos; statistics show the American publishing industry is overwhelmingly white. Several new groups of writers, editors and agents are out to change that.
Hunger is one of the most urgent — yet hidden — crises facing the nation. In this special episode of All Things Considered, a look at how food insecurity has been exacerbated by the coronavirus.
